Fair use guidelines are a set of principles that allow for limited use of copyrighted material without permission from the copyright owner. These guidelines take into account the purpose and character of the use, the nature of the copyrighted work, the amount and substantiality of the portion used, and the effect on the market for the copyrighted work.

Here are some specific instances of copyright infringement and how fair use guidelines may apply:

1. A teacher photocopies a few pages of a textbook for classroom use - This may be considered fair use as it is for educational purposes and only a small portion of the work is being used.

2. A blogger uses a copyrighted image in a blog post without permission - This may not be considered fair use as the image is being used for commercial purposes and the entire image is being used.

3. A student quotes a paragraph from a book in a research paper - This may be considered fair use as it is for educational purposes and only a small portion of the work is being used.

4. A musician samples a few seconds of a copyrighted song in their own recording - This may be considered fair use as it is a transformative use and only a small portion of the work is being used.

5. A YouTuber uploads a full-length movie without permission - This is not considered fair use as it is not a transformative use and the entire work is being used.

In each of these instances, the fair use guidelines must be applied on a case-by-case basis, considering all the factors mentioned above
